title: 107_s216
content: The Act titled "Commission on the Comprehensive Study of Voting Procedures Act of 2001" addresses concerns about voting procedures, speed, accuracy, and security of vote counts. It acknowledges the increasing use of technology in elections and calls for standardizing voting procedures to ensure the integrity of Federal elections. The Commission on the Comprehensive Study of Voting Procedures is established by the Act. The Commission's duties include implementing a matching grant program. The Commission on the Comprehensive Study of Voting Procedures will conduct a thorough study on voting procedures in Federal, State, and local elections, including best practices, legislation, standardized technology, speed, and accuracy of vote counts. The Commission on the Comprehensive Study of Voting Procedures will develop recommendations for Federal elections matters, including accuracy, security, and accessibility of voting procedures. They will also assess the funding needed for modernizing State and local voting procedures. A final report will be submitted to the President within 180 days after the study period. The Commission on the Comprehensive Study of Voting Procedures will submit a detailed final report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. They may also submit interim and additional reports with dissenting opinions. After the final report, the Attorney General will implement a Matching Grant Program. The Attorney General will award grants to State and local governments to implement recommendations made by the Commission on Voting Procedures. To be eligible, governments must submit an application and agree to provide matching funds. The Attorney General will determine grant amounts based on Commission recommendations. Appropriations are authorized for modernizing State and local voting procedures for Federal elections. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of five voting members appointed by the President, Senate majority leader, Senate minority leader, Speaker of the House, and House minority leader, along with the Director of the Office of Election Administration of the Federal Election Commission as a nonvoting member. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission, consisting of five members appointed by key officials, must be established within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, meetings are called by the Chairperson or majority, with the first meeting held within 30 days of all appointments. A majority constitutes a quorum, and a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are selected from among the members. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, meetings are called by the Chairperson or majority, with the first meeting held within 30 days of all appointments. A majority constitutes a quorum, and a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson are selected from among the members. The Commission has powers as outlined in Section 6. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, establish a website for public participation, and use postal services as needed. The Commission can contract for services, accept gifts, and receive administrative support from the General Services Administration to carry out its duties under this Act. SEC. 7. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on the level IV of the Executive Schedule for each day of duty. Government officers or employees serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided at authorized rates for employees of agencies. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. They can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON CONTRACTING AUTHORITY. Any new contracting authority in this Act is effective only as provided in appropriations Acts. SEC. 9. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission ends 30 days after submitting its report. SEC. 10. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not prevent enacting voting procedures during the Commission's duties. SEC. 11. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Sums necessary for the Commission are authorized, available without fiscal year limit.
